I played this game on the ps4 and I enjoyed it! I thought it was an interesting storyline and the difficulty level on normal was good enough for me to handle (I am not great at games). However, I recently got a new pc and decided to buy the game again because I heard of all the new updates and DLC, and it is like a whole new game. The skill tree is seamless and feels like it has a lot more weight to it. The weapon system is much more understandable. I haven't got to the new DLC but I am excited to see how it adds to the story. Overall, its super fun to replay and discover new ways to play the game!

it's definitely one of my favourite game, I'm now at the last boss: the stone monkey, for me the best chapter is the Spiderweb Hollow, Loved the story and boss fight, btw, the Yellow long took me like more than 20 fights, definitely the hardest fight for me, the best part of the game would be the fighting scene and responsive moves, definitely recommend it

Really interesting to see Chinese mythology portrayed like this in a video game. Not too familiar with it personally, so it was a nice breath of fresh air. 

The combat is fun and there's a lot of build variety. Sometimes the controls can feel a bit janky (feels like commands aren't queued up properly if your character is busy in an animation so it feels like you have to spam buttons to get one command out sometimes).

The story was relatively interesting. The end chapter animations were a huge highlight and a wonderful little decompression moment after the (usually) intense chapter end bosses.

Areas looked very beautiful but I definitely felt like level design itself was a bit lacking (even if the environments were gorgeous). Some areas dragged on for far too long and were kind of samey (chapter 5 really felt like it would never end). 

Overall, I definitely enjoyed the game and felt like the time I spent with it was worth it. I'm looking forward to the DLC.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

ending made me cry.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. It does rather lag in the middle whilst you go and do other jobs to fill in time until the main plot resumes. However, this is more an issue with the genre rather than this DLC in particular.
The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. I haven't experienced that kind of make you sit back and reflect on the things that you did to get you where you had to go since Geralt found Ciri in The Witcher 3. I look forward to enjoying it again. Phantom Liberty is immersive story telling at its best.
One of the Best Story DLCs I've seen in recent years. Loved the story and sat a solid 10 minutes at the end pondering what decisions to make.

An extremely well polished thriller. I was absolutely hooked! As I mentioned in my review of the base game, the decisions you make in the base game and DLC, and their consequences stay in your mind even long after you're done playing the game.

The game is in a very good state now than it was at launch, and I highly recommend playing it now if you didn't back when it launched.

Before I get into the negatives, I want to be very clear: this is one of my favorite games ever. I am a huge fan of the 2018 GoW, and this game actually improves on it in nearly every way. I wish that I could be writing a positive review right now, because this game absolutely deserves it... on console.

I bought the steam port the second it came out, and ever since, it has been fundamentally broken. I have no idea why most other reviewers aren't commenting on this, but this port is unplayable as it stands. I can repeatedly cause it to crash to desktop simply by looking at the in-game menus. If you want to read the in game lore, the game will crash the second you select any other item than the one it initially opened on, eg. Kvasir's Poems. The game also crashes during certain fights seemingly at random. And all of this will occur after closing the game and reopening to play later from your last save, which is a very normal thing to do.

I am running the game on an asus zephyrus laptop, with a 3080 gpu, as well as 8gb of vram. I am well within the bounds of recommended specs, and run intensive games all the time with no problems whatsoever. I have tried almost every combination of settings, both in and out of the game, but to no avail. I have scoured what little there is online, and amazingly, turning it off and on again doesn't fix an in-game bug, or bugs.

I have to imagine that all the good reviews are from people who haven't picked up this game since the first time opening it, or who have only played it on console. When this bug, or bugs, is fixed, I will immediately come back and edit this review to be glowing. But in the meantime, I encourage everyone to stay far away until it is fixed, and play the console version instead.

Game requires a restart every so often to avoid performance loss from VRAM usage going up and up with loading and transitioning between different realms and other assets not getting flushed fast enough from GPU memory. 

If you have less than a 16GB GPU you can experience issues earlier (depending on your in-game settings and resolution) like audio de-sync, texture pop-in and crashes. There are many other issues with the use of different controllers and issues with mouse and keyboard input. 

I will now sit on the wait train for patches.

Great game on the PS5. Worst PC port I've seen in a while. They're boasting steam deck compatibility, but the controls are so broken on the deck you cannot complete certain puzzles. Essentially locking you from progressing. Something is also broken on regular PC with PlayStation controllers. Took me ages to get R1 to work, and the controller will randomly quit working. It's not the controller as it works fine on any other game I use. Also crashed a few times while fiddling in the steam controller menu. Whoever was in charge of controller/steam deck support for this game needs to get fired. It's a shame, because the game is great, but can't reccomend a game this broken. Will change if they address the issues.

I have gotten to the mission with Atreus and [spoiler]Angrboda[/spoiler] and I have to take a break from this game as this mission in particular is a pungent combination of every aspect that makes this game so awful...

[*] The game features an Incredibly drawn out level design that forcefully diverts attention from the main objective without creating any sort of interest in whatever else that's going on. 
[*] The dialogue/voice acting takes away from the immersion of the mission and rarely adds anything of substance to the world (Sindri, Brock, and a few others are exceptions to this). 
[*] The combat system feels inconsistent and fights including bosses feel less "cool" then in the other games. 
[*] The puzzles/path discovery needed to advance within missions feels redundant, unoriginal, and often times unnecessary. 
[*] And IMO the armor/weapon upgrade UI feels unrefined and outdated. 

These issues are dramatically present in the mission mentioned above but are featured throughout the ~9 hours of gameplay I've experienced so far.

On the plus side the graphics and cut scenes look amazing, and the main story so far is awesome, in spite of how hard the developers tried to destroy the interesting aspects of the story through an incredibly poorly thought out gameplay experience. 

IMO this game is nowhere near worth the $60 price tag and I heavily regret spending that amount on this game. I would seriously wait for it to go on sale somewhere below the $30 mark. 

I will most likely end up completing the main story, just for nostalgias sake, and immediately uninstall it.

Memory leak preventing me from playing longer than an hour at a time. Come on now, this shouldn't happen for a game of this caliber.

I'm really just not enjoying this. It's very slow moving story wise with loads of places where you can only move your character around slowly in game. I usually love games with loads of interaction between characters but so much of the dialogue is bad and dull that this is one of the few games where I want to skip scenes. Worst of all for me though is that there are permanently missable items, such as a materia at the start of the game that you can never get again if you miss it. That's just bad design.

Combat is fine. There is an option for letting your guys auto attack so you can focus on commands but if you do that battles take soooooooo long whereas they go fast if you just mash x. I can see what they were trying to do and it looks cool to watch but playing it feels unfocused and you because everything is in such frenetic action, you can't appreciate the art assets or models at all

Overall this game feels bloated and boring with intentionally slow parts padding out the play time.

Bro I'm playing this on a Strix GTX 960 w 12gb ram and 3ghz dual core from 12+ years ago and running this at 60fps via display port @ 1920x1080. Beyond well optimized. Its easily one of my favorite games to play right now.

Aside from running well, this game has been everything I wanted it to be and then some. Compared to the vibe of original FF7, I think this does it a lot of justice. The characters and dialogue are fun, the Shinra menace is equally pronounced etc.

The combat is so smooth I don't even know where to start. But somehow they made a turn-based FF game feel completely naturally FF in an action RPG environment. It's great.

The pacing is good, the side quests are cute and rewarding. I feel like I wasn't wasting much time if any in this game. Everything just sorta flows when you figure out the map.

I can praise this game all day. I'm on the last chapter as of today - I only have a few issues:

-The humor can be out of place sometimes along with the fan service. Particularly when you hear Tifa say 'Man I really need a shower' for the 40th time after a fight it sorta makes you raise an eyebrow, genuinely. That crap is NOT why I'm here and it's sad to me that these adults designing these games find it adds anything to this kinda game.

-I get there is world building and the game GENUINELY at times feels like a re-imagined PS1 game but at times I feel like I'm running down long hallways for no real reason. Are the narrow passages you have to side-step through like...loading screens? Some places are just too big dude. 

-Collect-a-thon. As much as I like that and enjoy it in FF games, this game goes a little too far with the ground clutter. Way too many boxes to destroy. Personally I prefer ~80% of my items to be bought/earned from fights but I'd reckon 70-80% of your important items are in yellow-lit boxes and the battle rewards are mostly for gil. Is what it is. Not necessarily a bad thing, but I would probably enjoy *an hour or 2* Less destroying boxes on the ground.

I have much love for the original version, down to every last detail. There are pros and cons for someone like myself. I love the graphics and how they've been redone. I love the voices given to the characters. I love how interactive the game is, and it doesn't have to cut to a "movie" scene as in previous Final Fantasy games. I don't mind the slight change in the leveling/batting system. It feels more fluid, yet I can access the menu to choose what I want to do for the character I'm controlling. Is it complete control over all the characters with ATB? No. However, for this remake, it feels right. Moving onto changes in the story. There are a lot I agree with, and it was nice to have a change. However, I also felt a lot didn't need a change. That is my opinion, and you must make up your own. It's still a fantastic game, and I love it.

Ace Combat 7 is a vary good game and highly detailed but its also not the most realistic game but its fun.

I'll break this down simply.
The most realistic parts of this game and series as a whole:
- The look of the aircraft, ordinance, and effects.
- Some of the atmospheric effects: weather, vector trails, vapour, albeit no contrails above FL300ish as of yet.
- The diversity in aircraft types.
- The air battle management dialogue and presentation, which is fairly well depicted for a video game. It's clear that they consulted with real Tactical Air Traffic controllers on some level.
- The depiction of Tactical Data Link in a practical sense, especially with regard to ID classification.
- Playtime WRT length of missions.
- Plot points such as electronic warfare, drones, AI.
The least realistic parts:
- Let's be honest, ammunition load-out storage. Ridiculous. But the missions would be 5 minutes long, force you to land and take off repeatedly, or only have a couple land targets and a single enemy fighter group otherwise.
- Mechanics of fighter jet flight. Totally ridiculous. But fun and arcade-esque.
- Mechanics of air weapon flight. Ridiculous to keep up with the aircraft they are targeting. Fair enough.
- Fidelity of radar, comms, and link coverage. Not realistic for things to just work perfectly everywhere always. Just a game though.
- Plot points such as gigantic aircraft carriers, rail guns, and space elevators. Too expensive in the real world to ever make sense. Alluring as a fantasy depiction for sure.
- Pilot response to the ridiculous acceleration/deceleration and +/-G forces. That is not at all depicted in the series during gameplay. However it is mentioned in cutscenes.
- Supersonic depiction, something that I have only seen accurately depicted in flight simulator.
- It would be cool to have an depiction of Mach, IAS, and TAS if not for pure effect.
- It would be cool to have the cockpit depict information completely much like the VR presentation.

If I missed anything... well you'll see. I highly recommend any game in this series. This is the best seller for a reason but the story is a little more compelling in AC4 and its subsequent releases. Hopefully one day we will get remakes and remasters because these games have a lot of replayability and the older titles are kind of forgotten given their generation. The developers don't have to improve too much to keep fans happy, aside from a better multiplayer experience and some minor touch-ups, such as inaccurate sound effects and a storyline that isn't really very sad.

While the story of this game is very rich and immersive, I would recommend waiting for an optimization patch before truly investing yourself into this game. My PC meets all the recommended requirements but after every "fix" found on youtube and reddit, the game is playable for about 15 minutes before the frames completely drop again. I can restart my pc, try a new "fix" get 144fps for about 15 minutes until I change areas or start a boss fight before the frames crash again. It completely ruins the immersion of the game. Very unfortunate as the story and game play are both wonderful. Highly recommend the game, just don't ruin your initial experience until they optimize the game better.

RTX 4070TI, 64 GIGS DDR5, I9 13900k (without the temp issue), installed on a EVO 990 PRO. 

The fact that I still have to go find a fan-made mod for this to fix the issues that SE left in (graphics debugging enabled, 30 fps no frame-gen on cut-scenes, no ultrawide support etc etc) is annoying... but once you find it on nexusmods and pop it in the folder, the game runs and looks stellar. 

I played through this on PS5 but honestly wasn't impressed w/ the graphics / performance even on "performance mode", on PC it is great. 

Sure it's not your "usual" Final Fantasy game, but the story is definitely a Final Fantasy story. Heavy themes, decently likable characters with actual characteristics that aren't 'tailored for a modern audience' and 2 expansion packs (1 that's decent for a hallway sim, and 1 that is freaking amazing). 

Is it worth 70 bucks to get the 'complete' edition? Nah, I wouldn't say so... but if you do some browsing / googling you should be able to find a discounted cdkeys from some (dot)com out there that is around 40-50 for the complete edition... and that is definitely worth it if you enjoy the series.

Gameplay
The strong point of the game, it does well what FFXV did poorly but despite that the magic system is still inferior to the rest of the series, not as bad as the one in FF XV but VII Remake and Lightning Returns are better action FFs in their magic system, if you liked DMC V and likes FF you're still going to like the gameplay.

Maps
Noting really impressive, the game is actually better in the corridor sections than in their multiple big areas, but nothing  quite as good as the secrets or freedom that you have in FF XII, it doesn't help that there are fell dungeons and that they are locked behind the story(you can replay them at any moment).

Story
Despite the good start the story is probably the worst I have experienced in a FF game, it tries to be too serious but the western style storytelling doesn't fit with the themes of a FF story, Clive is an adult that acts like a depressive teenager, the game tries to make you fell sympathy for what the characters had to go through but it just fell forced, like the fact the protagonist was "forced" into slavery for 13 years, and it's not just slavery that felt forced, one moment you are invading a country and another you are helping a whore protect a city? there is a good lore to make things interesting but they didn't know what to focus and ended up half-assing everything.
If the game didn't have so many side stories and focused more on the main cast like FF XV did it would had been a lot better but it ends up taking the story too serious for what it is.

I would recommend the game if there was less story but because the game has so many cutscenes it's hard to separate it from the game, there are good moments but the bad ones are really bad, at least we the gameplay carries the game for me.
so far great story line. Love the graphics. So BEAUTIFUL in so many ways. fighting style is unique but fun

Would absolutely recommend, Clive is 100% top 3 best protagonists in the history of FF, and I have been playing since FF1. The Mature rating is a welcomed addition - which I hope continues - especially for players who have been around since the beginning. 
With each FF are new features being tested and previous dynamics from games still being perfected. The story is deep, the game play is fierce, and the cinematics are gorgeous.
Is it different than previous installments? Yes, but that is what we have come to expect and I for one, look forward to the future, if they keep building upon this bold new direction.

Playing through this for the first time in Sept. 2024, it's clear why FFXIV: Dawntrail's MSQ was the way it was; the A-Team at CBU-3 was developing FFXVI. Koji-Fox, come back, we miss you and your jokes. And we don't want Poochie anymore.

I was pulled into FFXVI's world in a way that XIII and XV both failed to. I can see so much of FFXIV's influence not just in the excellent production and storytelling, but in the game's refusal to waste your time for no reason. i.e. Once you've been somewhere you can fast-travel there, *optional* side-quests along the way, rewards for just playing through, clearly marking side-quests that are special, etc.

Can't say enough about the sound, it's fantastic. Whether it's the music, sound effects, or the (English) voice acting, it's clear that it got a lot of attention.

Graphics are gorgeous. Easily one of the best looking games on PC today. Very much glad to have waited to play this title on PC.

Game play is pretty much on the same direction as XV. If you don't like action combat, well... then it's not for you. I loved FF: Stranger of Paradise, and I like FFXVI's system. While this is nowhere near as punishing, it can still offer a reasonable challenge. At the same time, it actually has difficulty settings and the ability to further reduce challenge, if desired, via special accessories you get out of the gate. Skill system is fine IMO, let's you customize the way you like to play without giving you a full-blown autistic PoE-style circuit to deal with.

Story? It's dark, depressing, but very well-told some 18 hours in at this point. Tons of lore to explore and flesh out the world for those interested. But it is not necessary to study in-game lore to enjoy the story. If you like immersing yourself in your game's world, it's there for you. Otherwise, they don't waste your time by forcing you to read it.

The people complaining that it's not a true FF game because it isn't turn-based need to get real... I'd wager some few of them were probably the same ones bagging on Lost Odyssey and Blue Dragon for "being behind the times" and still having turn-based, menu-driven, combat systems when those titles came out ~17 years ago.

Also, it has a free demo. If you're not sure that FFXVI is your cup of tea, try the demo. Your opinion is worth way more than mine when it comes to spending your own $50. And it's damn sure worth more than xXStrifeCloudiroth420Xx's retard-tier take that it's bad because Final Fantasy peaked in 1997. (Spoiler: That guy bought the FFXVI Complete Edition anyway and somehow managed to put over 400 hours into it within the first week it was out.)

As a Final Fantasy veteran this game is wonderful. the franchise as come a long way from turn based battles to 3-D active battles after so many attempts at it. the break in it came with FF 15 then with FF 7 Remake and the Remake of Crisis Core. The story is very well put together in my opinion. I like the use of more everyday language that really gets the story going. earlier titles sure lacked that, it is a welcomed upgrade. To make this game shine, playing it on any console doesn't do it justice. even a PS 5 Pro, very expensive and still can't do much better. 
Recommended Hardware: Yes I am a Pro machine builder. 
I7 or I9 16-24 Core CPU
64 GB of System Memory or more DDR4 or 5
NVIDA RTX 4080 16 GB Video if you can catch a sale on it. 
M2 PCI 4.0 or 5.0 SSD Drive. on a Mainboard that supports it. a second drive for the windows page file helps too.

Played damn near every Final Fantasy.  13 and 15 were pretty bad.  The story in this one is good.  Very easy gameplay.  More of an ARPG.  But very fun and great story.

While I'm definitely in it for the ride, I can't recommend it before someone gets to know what they are in for.
The first act of the game until the first major boss fight is amazing, makes you go "hell yeah" every five minutes.
Most of the trailer footage is from that part too, and there lies the problem.

What I call "Act 2" starting out in "Three Reeds" is just awful padding, you constantly spend five meters lollygagging before a cutscene or someone wants to either tell you their life story, you to tell them yours or even both, with a minute or so of combat scattered around and the game just continues like that.

You want to get to the next part of the gang's "big plan" but first you need to get through an hour long filler arc between actual plot continuity, you could easily cut a third of the game's runtime worth of redundant cutscenes and five to 50 meter walking sections to trigger another cutscene.
A beautiful game it will forever be my top 5 i loved every second of it
First, it looks fun. after few hours, it's growing boring in every acts. Idk, maybe just me.
Loving the direction they're taking the franchise.

This is like Game of Thrones story telling mixed with Devil May Cry or God of War battle system. 
Everything is great, 
- Story
- Battle System
- Graphics
- Fun
- Amazing Sound Track

Some negatives: Some of the busy work quests do get stale and some parts do get kind of stutter and frames drop.

Personally as a long time final fantasy fan I really enjoyed it. I think when all said and done it will be right up there with some of the other top entries of the franchise.

FYI: For Achievement Hunters: you do need the DLC to get all achievements

I see a lot of people complaining about performance issues and honestly I've never had not one. I have been loving it so far. I run 1440 at 100 frames on max settings with a 4060 ti. Final Fantasy XVI is a masterfully-created game full of action, adventure and RPG elements that coalesce to create an experience like no other.

The game is visually stunning, especially in some of the story's big moments. The graphics are certainly up-to-date and look absolutely wonderful.
In terms of combat, it's a gradually-unfolding library of abilities and options that doesn't stop pouring more and more depth out to the player, which I can safely assume doesn't stop throughout the course of the game's entire story. I haven't finished the game, being only 24 hours into it, but I can safely say that the way things are structured lets you know that you'll never be at a loss for more new powers and attacks to use. I  would say the combat in this game strays from the usual of this franchise, and the developers opted for real-time button-masher slice-and-dice type of combat instead of the turn-based JRPG combat. Some similarities I can safely make are the God of War franchise and the Devil May Cry franchise, where you have a vast array of skills you can chain together in intense, fast-paced slash-and-dash combat. As I mentioned before, the combat capabilities of both Clive and his companions increases constantly throughout the game's main story campaign, starting off somewhat limited and slower-paced, with not much potential for chaining abilities or juggling an enemy with combos. However, later during the game, many options are presented to you and you can craft your own array of powers to channel depending on what you like best.

There is a skill tree, although it is much more simplistic and very surface-level compared to other games in the genre. I find this to be a positive, as I would much rather spend my time playing the game than stuck in the menus trying to navigate a digital library of damage and armor numbers.

The story is absolutely enthralling, with a lovable cast of characters each with their own personalities and personal stories. Clive is a wonderful protagonist with an incredible voice actor and a perfectly-structured list of motivations that shifts in a very sensible and relatable way throughout the game's story. You get to see the entire tale unfold right from the beginning and even from other characters' perspectives at times.
I would draw a comparison between this and George R.R Martin's Game of Thrones, as the political aspects of the world's nations and interactions between their powerful figures, their plots and their schemes, intertwines with the fantastical nature of FFXVI's realm to create a very, very immersive story.

This is only my second Final Fantasy game, having only played FF15 before this. I can easily say that this time around, the game's story and worldbuilding is on an entirely different level of maturity. It is darker, grittier, and more brutal, and the game does a great job expressing this in its cutscenes, the carefully-designed environments, and the dialogue of the characters. There is even an NPC that comes up during the main story, which educates the protagonist on the state of the world, really delivering more information and lore to the player as part of a collection of entertaining cutscenes.

This game's boss fights are some of the most epic and memorable I've seen in any video game. There are amazing massive-scale fights that feel almost addictive, and really spark a flame of that power fantasy for the player. I can't say any more without spoilers, but if you're looking for some visually-stunning large-scale boss fights, you can't do much better than this game, save for maybe the God of War franchise or Shadow of the Colossus.

As for performance, I am running this on an i9 with a 3060ti and 32gb ram. The game runs very smoothly often times for me, with a bit of roughness on day 1 of PC release. My computer restarted a few times when playing this game, but that issue has faded away entirely. Over the course of my 24 hours of gameplay, I've experienced only 1 or 2 second-long brief patches of FPS loss, which did not happen very often. Maybe once or twice per session, during the particularly weighty moments where there was alot to see on-screen.

The only problems with this game are as follows:

I find the pacing to be rather slow between the big main story moments. It's fine and dandy to run around doing normal things every once in a while, but sometimes it drags out a tiny bit and it feels a little like a chore. Despite this, the game's story uses the time it is given by the slow pacing to further flesh out the characters. Turning the bad into good, I suppose - I like it :)

Loot - the game throws out new weapons, armor pieces and accesories at you, which have their own numbers and effects that can be pretty interesting. However, there isn't really any time during the game where you'd defeat an enemy and your jaw would drop because you got a rare piece of loot, that kind of joy isn't made available by this game, unfortunately. The weapons do change the visuals of Clive's sword, but mechanically, all they change is a number. It would've been nice to see some of the weapons or armor pieces being a little bit more involved in combat than simply changing around the number of damage you do in a hit, or how much HP you have, and such.

There is little in the way of customization. At some point in the game, you do gain the ability to change Clive and his companions' appearance, by selecting one of some outfits that are made available to you. I find this extremely limited, and I'd love the ability to change around individual pieces of Clive's armor. That's alot to ask for, so I'd settle for just a few more outfits to be made available in the game. FF15 was the same way, but that one had quite a few more options than FF16.

That's all I can say for this game. I can see myself playing it all the way through and I'm super excited for everything that comes next :)
That being said, my rating for this game is a solid 9/10. If you're a fan of hacking and slashing through enemies, navigating a fantastical world with carefully-designed environments, and being immersed in a wonderful and interpersonal story, FFXVI is the game for you
